Abstract: Galactic dynamos play a crucial role in generating and maintaining large-scale magnetic fields observed in spiral galaxies, including our own Milky Way. This study investigates the mechanisms behind these dynamos and their impact on galactic evolution. We analyze observational data from multiple spiral galaxies and employ numerical simulations to model the complex interplay between galactic rotation, turbulence, and magnetic field amplification. Our results demonstrate that the magnetic Reynolds number, a key parameter in dynamo theory, is significantly higher in the circumgalactic medium than previously thought, leading to more efficient field generation. We find that the large-scale magnetic fields extend far beyond the visible disk, influencing the dynamics of the circumgalactic medium and potentially affecting gas accretion and outflows. Furthermore, we identify a correlation between the strength of the large-scale magnetic field and the star formation rate in spiral galaxies, suggesting a feedback mechanism between magnetic fields and galactic evolution. These findings provide new insights into the origin and maintenance of galactic magnetic fields and their role in shaping the structure and evolution of spiral galaxies like the Milky Way.
